pros:
One word: Benefits. Twenty hours a week gets you health insurance, "free" tuition through ASU, free mental therapy programs, 401K matching, free Spotify Premium, in addition to a bunch of other cool stuff. 

Super flexible hours. Free coffee and food. 

You will also meet some really cool (and not so cool) people working here. Every "partners" experience is different.
cons:
I have been with the company for almost ten years. I truly do love my job, the people I work with, and the customers I serve. Having said that, expect to work hard. You will always be multitasking as there are never enough partners on the floor. Do not expect to be compensated for your "above and beyond" skills. In the end, Starbucks is okay. In order to survive, you really need to become a part of the cult that it is and drink the Koolaid. Your store manager plays the greatest role in your experience.

Don't be fooled by the whole "inspiring and nurturing the human spirit" and 
"connection" mumb-jumbo. It's just another corporate marketing strategy.

review_title: Poor Pay, no explanation of benefits
pros: free beverages, nice co-workers, nice training protocols
cons:
Made $9 as a supervisor who trained people at multiple stores. Managers were either men or women who were masculine, being feminine in any way was considered weakness in my district. The benefits were never explained, so if you signed up for a bad package, you were stuck with it for a year. I chose a package that cost 1/3 of my check for an entire year, and my checks already didn't cover my basic utility expenses. 

I became a trainer and shift supervisor, so I could make just over $9 an hour, and the manager would continuously hire people I'd interviewed and determined were not a good fit and when he came to the conclusion after hiring them that they were a terrible fit, he would put them on my shifts so he wouldn't have to work with them. I had one girl who cried at her interview when I asked her why she wanted to work for Starbucks. She cried every day at work. I trained her, trained her, trained her... she cried every day. It was very disruptive to the workplace.

I wasn't given enough staff on my shifts, so I had to work through my lunches and stay late off the clock. They tell you not to do that, but also get upset when things aren't done, even when you work the busiest shifts with half the staff that manager gives themselves on their slower shifts.

I did most of my manager's job for him, and it was beyond thankless. I did the deep cleaning, the schedule, the ordering, the inventory, and called for maintenance when my manager refused to do it.

review_title: Good benefits but base pay lacking

- Good perks / Free food and drinks during shifts, a pound of coffee beans to take home every week, free Spotify premium, health benefits
- Good working environment - safe with better employees than typical fast food restaurants
cons:
- despite good benefits, base pay lags behind. (many Starbucks are $9 an hour -- could work in a Target Starbucks for a minimum wage of $15 instead)
- high stress environment - depends on the store but the store is typically busy all day leading to a fast-paced and stressful environment the whole shift
- typically understaffed - management wants to push for faster window times and better customer connection all while cutting labor hours. People are often expected to do two roles during their shift.
- Lack of advancement opportunities - while it is fairly easy to be promoted to a shift manager and even a store manager, getting higher positions in corporate is difficult as they typically hire outside the company

But if you are overworked it's usually because the team lead has a huge stick up their butt against you.

pros: great health insurance with a competitive price/ Lyra mental sessions/ free coffee and food/ flexible hours/
cons:
1. Store managers definitely play favoritisms towards certain partners. 
2. When a barista transfer to a new store, he/she may be experience workplace bullying, this happens more obvious in popular stores like Starbucks reserve stores where every partner wants to get in. --- that brings up the toxic competition and retaliation environment. 
3. If the management does not "favor" you, they will delay or reject your application to move up, using all kinds of excuses. Threatens happen all the times behind the doors. 
4. Extremely toxic work environment and retaliation if some partners do not like you/your personality from the beginning, they constantly looking for excuses to expel you from their store.
5. Lack of communication, SM and SSV will NOT care you from a basic humanity level and they will put you in the most uncomfortable position to work. They do not care about you, they care about only money. 
6. If you cannot hand out a drink to them within 30 seconds during peak rush time at a drive through store, they will send you to clean the bathroom and tables. --- you felt completely worthless. They say this is good for you and they care about you, but you need to see the truth --- they do not trust you and destroy your confidence, they want money only. They do not care about their partners as the company indicates. They say they care by provide all kinds of insurances benefits but thats not worth the mental/physical stresses you have. 
6. They provide good health insurance for your mental/physical breakdowns at work, so find a happier place to work can save you a lot of money for your insurance. 
7. 90% of the partners have chronic back pain, mental breakdowns and muscle sore, hand injury etc. from work.

review_title: Experience at Starbucks Highly Depends on Location
pros:
-free coffee every week
-healthcare benefits
-free drinks when working 
-free food when working
-College achievement program
-relaxed management style
-the fall/winter is usually pretty slow
-always hiring (and interview process is not hard--will hire anyone)
cons:
-experience varies from store to store (worked in NJ/Seattle)
-NJ Specific: management is more interested in numbers than employees
-often asked to stay past scheduled hours (10-hour shifts are pretty normal)
-many call-outs (frustrating as a shift)
-usually understaffed
-high turnover rate (had over 30 different people quit or transfer)
-night crew is expected to do FAR more work than day staff (and day staff often criticize your performance--don't take it personally)
-lack of professionalism or accountability (people can no call, no show and nothing happens, many employees are regularly late, employees who slack off aren't told anything, management doesn't fire anyone--even when there are weekly customer complaints about an employee)
-customers at this particular store in Edgewater are very rude (other NJ stores I've worked at were fine though)

review_title: Bad Training, Low Pay, No Support.
pros: They rotate you on all the hours so you can feel the patterns of the store in the very beginning. But if they do not like a staff member they will on purpose give you shifts that coincide with school or Homelife/children to push you out - and there is no one to go to about this. I saw 2 staff members leave for this. you need to be in University with very open schedule or a submissive new immigrant. The people who became corporate and have jobs designing cups will al imply they were Baristas but if you check, they all knew someone corporate (big clique). Or they keep it off their linkedin like it never happened - so maybe it didn't....They share all their other previous basic jobs!
cons: Managers "train" you by reading a sales flyer of the upcoming seasonal items - much like reading you a menu. They cannot tell you the ingredients, and the large batch items come from manufacturer or supplier without ingredient list (mostly) so you don't know what you're giving people. Those of us staff with gluten or dairy issues or vegetarian/vegan (Toronto is full of us!) we would NEVER drink the mixed drinks, fraps etc...and we would get written up if we didn't sell a specific amount of their premium clover coffees. So we had a sales requirement number (i.e. 10 clovers in 3 hours) during our shifts we had to stuff down peoples throats. Customers eventually started coming to the counter to say they didn't want clover before making their actual orders. The Managers imply the location is "their business" so when a Barista (off probation) would like to switch locations, they say " it would not be good for my reputation and business to let you switch to work at another location because - - - but it is not their ability to hold you hostage when another location will take you and wants the new staff. The Managers are given too much room to decide no one is able to transfer, and too much gatekeeping. A lot of turnover at this highest performing location in Toronto. If you quit they don't call you in for your last tips - they quietly keep your tips and ignore your calls. (Not just for me!). Our location never got the fake "sensitivity training" btw...

pros:
Free coffee 
Usually your co workers are pretty nice! 
Decent job for students
Benefits are good for full time
cons:
Pretty much everything else. I will give the skinny on exactly what I didn’t like about the job. 

1. Customers are very demanding and rude. I’ve worked in other coffee shops and never experienced the rude customers I did at Starbucks. Verbal abuse is pretty normal from customers. Very little is done about it. 

2. Pay, the pay is bad for the work you put in. You bust your butt from the second you get there to when you leave for minimum wage. Extremely stressful rushes. Not worth the money. You get tips but they are so small. Like $5 a week. They say oh you get tips but fail to mention that. 

3. Management has insane expectations. Like insane productivity goals and sales goals. Staff are “cut” even when it’s busy because head office has these expectations that aren’t possible on the floor. 

I experienced little flexibility in my life. Starbucks expected me to be available even on days I said I can’t work. Hard to book time off and a huge culture against booking off time/taking breaks. Your life is expected to be Starbucks. You have to attend meetings even if you have a good reason. They are not flexible to accommodate students as much as they claim when you get hired. I got scheduled during my exams twice and got written up for “skipping” when I booked two months ago. Not really asking for much. I had a final exam and obviously couldn’t skip it for work. That notion a student should choose between keeping their job and taking two BOOKED days off-is crazy. It was a dumb reason to be “talked to” by my manager when I was always early, covered shifts and tried extremely hard. I’ve had a few jobs through school and only at Starbucks did I experience conflicts with school. It isn’t just my store, other friends at other stores experienced the same issues. 

Overall. I don’t recommend it. You can make more money at easier, more flexible food service jobs. It’s hard to balance school. They say school should be your priority but don’t listen to your requested days off for school, while manager favourites aka full time, long term people can book off literally any day. Lots of favouritism toward full time people who’ve been there years. They basically get any days off, any shifts and are always on their phones. I never saw any get talked to. Different rules exist for part time people than long term full time “lifers”. The bias is super obvious.

I also got injured and was unable to have a few days off. Despite a doctor saying I needed it, I had a note. I was guilt tripped into working with a badly sprained wrist because someone already had it booked off and they were short. I was basically told to suck it up and “be there for my team”. I was made to feel like a bad employee for falling and going to the hospital. My parents were upset I was forced to work, or once again I’d be written up. I hate being guilted or pressured to come in injured/sick/on booked days

pros: Free food? But the company policy is that you only get one food item a day. Depending on the city you're in the pay is better than minimum, though in this day and age it's still a pathetic amount.
cons:
Psychotic company culture that expects fanatical cult-like devotion to... *checks notes* serving mediocre fast food coffee. 

Thousands of jargon-y routines and subroutines you're expected to memorize and complete without variance despite the fact that none of these routines accomplish literally anything of importance-- ie, you will get scolded like a misbehaving dog if you pumped the frap base and the flavored syrup into the blender in the wrong order even though it's all getting blended up regardless. That's just an example but it goes for every single aspect about the job you can imagine. As someone who has worked in food service a while: it aint that serious.
